Starting June 1, child care providers can decide to reopen if they follow health and safety precautions. Some may choose not to reopen or are unable to do so. Find more information on child care from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.

question: How can I keep from getting sick if I live with or care for someone who is sick with COVID-19?
answer: The CDC has advice to protect yourself or others if you are caring for someone with COVID-19. You can learn what to do when someone has symptoms of COVID-19, when someone has been diagnosed with COVID-19, or when someone who has tested positive but is not showing symptoms. Read Caring for Someone Sick at Home and Guidance for Large or Extended Families Living in the Same Household from the CDC.

question: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
answer:
The Health Department is now including data about race and ethnicity on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. We recognized the need to include this information to help us understand how Vermonters were being affected by COVID-19, but in our earlier efforts to respond to the pandemic, race and ethnicity data was not always collected for each patient. A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont.
Health equity exists when all people have a fair and just opportunity to be healthy â especially those who have experienced socioeconomic disadvantage, historical injustice, and other systemic inequalities. Therefore, our epidemiology team collaborated with Vermont Information Technology Leaders (VITL) to cross-reference medical records to gain more robust race information about COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

question: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
answer:
As reports appear in the news of certain drugs being potentially used for treatment or prevention of COVID-19, the Vermont Department of Health strongly urges caution.
Though the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, among others, have been widely discussed as potential treatments, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said there are no data currently available from randomized clinical trials that would inform how these drugs could be used to treat COVID-19.
In fact, there are significant potential risks to taking such drugs, including death.
Health officials remind Vermonters that most people who get COVID-19 can manage their symptoms at home with rest, drinking fluids and taking fever-reducing medication. Talk to your health care provider before taking any substance alleged to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Providers should only prescribe these drugs for individuals with diagnosed conditions, and not for prevention, to help maintain the supply for Vermonters who need them.

question: Is there a vaccine for COVID-19? When will a vaccine be available?
answer: There is no vaccine for COVID-19, but research and work are underway to develop one.

question: How many people have recovered from COVID-19 in Vermont?
answer: The number of Vermonters who have recovered from COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. There is also information on this page for how the number of people recovered is reported.

question: How many people are being monitored in Vermont?
answer: The number of people being monitored is updated every day on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: How many cases of COVID-19 are in the U.S.?
answer: The CDC reports updated national numbers of COVID-19 cases and deaths.

question: How do I practice safer drug use?
answer:
The Harm Reduction Coalition has tips for safer drug use during the COVID-19 pandemic.Find a syringe service program near you.
Call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referral services at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.

question: Where do the test samples get processed?
answer:
As of March 20, 2020, health care providers submit samples to the University of Vermont Medical Center Laboratory (UVMMC) for prioritization. Samples from higher risk populations will be tested at the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory. Lower priority tests are done at commercial labs.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: Does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean I can be arrested or will need special papers if I leave my home?
answer:
Enforcement of the Governor's Stay Home, Stay Safe Order will be mainly be done through education and voluntary compliance.


The Order does not close roads and does not establish roadblocks or checkpoints.


Motor vehicle and pedestrian traffic will continue as Vermonters do outdoor activities that are allowed and travel to and from businesses (including grocery stores and pharmacies) and other entities that are allowed to operate under the Order.


There will not be motor vehicle stops or people detained for questioning about their travel, but law enforcement officers may be reminding people of the Order if they see groups gathering or businesses operating in violation of the Order.


Read the latest updates to the Stay Home, Stay Safe Executive Order.

question: How can I report a person or business who is violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order?
answer:
The Department of Public Safety and the Vermont State Police recommended to Vermont municipal leaders and law-enforcement executives that enforcement of the Governorâs Stay Home, Stay Safe Order be handled mainly through education and voluntary compliance.


For concerns about businesses or lodging facilities that are violating the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order, use the Department of Public Safetyâs non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.


For concerns or complaints about restaurants, use the Health Departmentâs online sanitation complaint form, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.


For employees to report alleged safety or health hazards, use the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administrationâs (VOSHA) confidential safety complaint form.


For complaints regarding individuals who are failing to self-quarantine, as required, please call your local law-enforcement agency.


Read the Attorney Generalâs Enforcement Directive.
Find out more about what the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order means to Vermonters.
Find sector-specific guidance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development for details on which businesses are open.

question: Is there universal (widespread) testing being done at group living facilities?
answer:
In Vermont, additional measures are being taken to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities. This includes nursing homes, corrections facilities, residential homes for people with disabilities, residential treatment centers, assisted living facilities, state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters. In the event of a COVID-19 positive staff or resident, universal testing of all staff and residents is offered at these facilities. Staff and residents may decline testing, and facilities may decline universal testing.
Additionally, when a person tests positive at a skilled nursing facility, sequential testing is offered to those who tested negative during the universal testing.

question: How can I help care for someone sick at home?
answer: The CDC has advice on how to protect yourself or others if you are caring for someone with COVID-19. You can learn what to do when someone has symptoms of COVID-19, when someone has been diagnosed with COVID-19, or when someone who has tested positive but is not showing symptoms. Read Caring for Someone Sick at Home.

question: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
answer:
Feeling anxious, confused, overwhelmed or powerless is common during an infectious disease outbreak. Taking care of yourself, your friends, and your family can help you cope with stress. Helping others cope with their stress can also make your community stronger.


Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories, including social media. Hearing about the pandemic repeatedly can be upsetting.


Take care of your body. Take deep breaths, stretch, or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, get plenty of sleep, and avoid alcohol and drugs.


Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy.


Connect with others. Talk with people you trust about your concerns and how you are feeling.


Find more information on coping with COVID-19 stress, including resources for local help, self-care, suicide prevention, and domestic violence.
Find more tips for coping with stress from the CDC, including how to help children cope with stress.
Need support right now?


Call your local mental health crisis line


Text VT to 741741


Call 2-1-1 or 1-866-652-4636


Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline or call 1-800-273-8255


For multilingual support, call 800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746

question: Is it safe to go to the hospital?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of a more serious medical condition, such as heart attack or stroke, it is important to get medical care right away. Call 9-1-1, go to the emergency room, or call your doctor if your symptoms are not life-threatening.
It is safe to seek care at Vermont hospitals. They have measures in place to protect patients in the hospital from getting COVID-19. This includes separating patients with COVID-19 from other patients. There is a greater risk to staying at home if you're experiencing symptoms of a serious medical condition than going to the hospital.
As of May 4, health care providers may also begin to do some clinic visits, diagnostic imaging, and outpatient surgeries and procedures again â as long as they have a minimal impact on inpatient hospital bed capacity and personal protective equipment (PPE). This does not include elective surgeries that require staying at the hospital, which are not permitted at this time. Read the Governorâs press release for details.

question: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
answer:
Yes, people with medical and health care skills and those with other needed skills can sign up for volunteer assistance to support the stateâs response to COVID-19. We currently have a contact tracing team in place, but these are other ways you can help.
People with medical or other health care backgrounds are needed to support the health care providers responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. Vermontâs Medical Reserve Corps units are community-based groups of volunteers who supplement local emergency and public health resources with their existing skills.
Sign up with the Vermont Medical Reserve Corps if you:


Are a licensed and certified health care professional


Have health, mental health, or other types of clinical or professional experience


Have health care administrative experience, such as with medical data entry or language translators


Have worked with displaced individuals, such as homeless shelter programs


Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purposes of aiding this emergency response. Physicians, physician assistants and podiatrists can learn more on the Board of Medical Practice website. Other medical professionals, including nurses and osteopathic physicians, can learn more on the Office of Professional Regulation's website.
Other individuals who have needed skills (for example, drivers, food service, construction, IT, security, skilled trades, etc.), can sign up at vermont.gov/volunteer and indicate their expertise and availability.
Vermonters can also contribute to blood banks, food banks, and other emergency supply efforts. The American Red Cross of Northern New England faces a severe blood shortage and many local food banks and other community organizations are in need of support and donations of supplies.
Give blood: Learn how to safely donate blood with the American Red Cross.
Support your local Foodbank by donating online or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511. The Vermont Foodbank can help if you need it.
You can also help your neighbors â older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions should stay home as much as possible. Go shopping for a neighbor or someone else in need, keep an older neighbor company by phone or at a safe distance. When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.

question: My health care provider is out-of-state. Can I be tested in Vermont?
answer: Yes, out-of-state health care providers can refer their patients for COVID-19 testing in Vermont. Ask your health care provider for a referral.

question: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
answer:
Making sure neighbors have what they need is crucial, but we need to make sure helpers and volunteers are still taking precautions to protect our most vulnerable Vermonters. Common sense practices can go a long way while Vermonters take care of each other.
The Vermont Department of Health recommends any volunteers bringing items to those who need to stay home:


Keep a distance of 6 feet away.


Avoid entering the personâs home.


Wear a cloth face mask or covering.


Wash your hands regularly.


Avoid touching your face and cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.


Stop doing community support work immediately if you feel sick or find out you have had contact with someone who is sick.


Keep a list of anyone you come into close contact with in case contact tracing is required.


Wear clean gloves when handling items that may be given to people with a weaker immune system, and when you are close to someone who may be sick.

question: Can I get unemployment? How do I file an unemployment claim?
answer:
Find out about unemployment related to COVID-19 from the Department of Labor.
Find answers to frequently asked questions about unemployment insurance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

question: What should colleges and universities who are planning student foreign travel do?
answer: Please read the guidance for institutions of higher education with students participating in foreign travel or study abroad programs from the CDC.

question: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
answer:
People who have fully recovered from COVID-19 have antibodies in their blood plasma. This is the bodyâs immune response to the virus. Currently, plasma donations are only being done experimentally. It has not yet been confirmed by the scientific community. However, it could prove to be important in the future to treating serious cases of illness from COVID-19.
The Red Cross is looking for people who are fully recovered from COVID-19 and may be able to donate plasma. If you are fully recovered from a COVID-19 diagnosis that was confirmed by a lab test and would like to donate your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.

question: Where can I find additional resources?
answer:
Visit CDCâs FAQs


Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCD) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center


Call the VT Department of Health call center at (802) 863-7240 to talk to a person


Call 2-1-1 (if callers are having trouble calling from a cell phone, turn off WiFi then call again)


If your question still isnât answered, email AHS.VDHPublicCommunication@vermont.gov

question: I donât feel safe at work. How can I share a safety complaint about my workplace related to COVID-19?
answer: Employees with COVID-19 related concerns in the workplace can contact the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administration (VOSHA). Employees can submit a confidential online safety complaint form, or call toll free at 1-800-287-2765.

question: What should Vermont community-based and faith-based organizations do?
answer: Read the Interim Guidance for Administrators and Leaders of Community- and Faith-Based Organizations to Plan, Prepare, and Respond to COVID-19 from the CDC.

question: What information is available for managers and owners of apartment complexes to help prevent the spread of COVID-19?
answer: For guidance on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of apartment complexes, visit healthvermont.gov/COVID19-groupliving. Find information for making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents or staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.

question: I don't have a house or a home, how can I stay safe?
answer: There is temporary housing available for people experiencing homelessness who are suspected to have or tested positive for COVID-19 and donât require hospitalization. Call the Vermont Economic Services Division at 802-479-6151 Monday through Friday between 8:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. After hours, you can call 2-1-1.

question: I have questions about financial assistance and housing.
answer: The Agency of Commerce and Community Development has answers to questions regarding financial assistance (for example mortgage, utility bills, internet, and taxes) and housing (for example, paying rent, short-term housing and emergency housing) on its COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.

question: What should health care workers do?
answer:
The Health Department now has a dedicated webpage for health care workers - healthvermont.gov/covid19-providers. It includes current guidance, health alerts, and resources for protecting patients and health care workers in different settings.
Report all suspected cases of COVID-19 immediately to the Vermont Department of Health Infectious Disease Epidemiology by calling 802-863-7240 (24/7).
If you suspect that a patient with a fever or respiratory illness has COVID-19:


Give the patient a surgical mask.


Notify facility infection control personnel immediately.


Use standard precautions, contact precautions, airborne precautions, and use eye protection when entering the room.


Evaluate the patient in a private room with the door closed, ideally in an airborne infection isolation room

question: Are syringe service programs (needle exchanges) still open?
answer:
Yes, services have been changed to limit in-person contact. Some services may not be available like walk-in HIV/Hepatitis C testing. Find a syringe service program near you.
Call VT Helplink for free, confidential alcohol and drug support and referral services at 802-565-LINK or search for a syringe service program.

question: Does sunlight kill the COVID-19 virus?
answer: Currently, the World Health Organization says there is no evidence that sunlight kills the COVID-19 virus.

question: What is the difference between COVID-19 and the flu?
answer:
COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning about how it makes people sick.
Cause
COVID-19: Caused by one virus, the novel 2019 coronavirus, now called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2.
Flu: Caused by any of several different types and strains of influenza viruses.
Transmission
While both the flu and COVID-19 may be transmitted in similar ways, there is also a possible difference: COVID-19 might be spread through the airborne route, meaning that tiny droplets remaining in the air could cause disease in others even after the ill person is no longer near.
Antiviral Medications
COVID-19: Antiviral medications are currently being tested to see if they can address symptoms.
Flu: Antiviral medications can address symptoms and sometimes shorten the duration of the illness.
Vaccine
COVID-19: No vaccine is available at this time, though it is in progress.
Flu: A vaccine is available and effective to prevent some of the most dangerous types or to reduce the severity of the flu.
Find out more about deaths and infections from Johns Hopkins Medicine.

question: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
answer:
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials, according to the CDC. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or an object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. However, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.
Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces daily are the best ways to help stop the spread of the COVID-19 virus in households and community settings.
Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfection for households guidance for more information.

question: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
answer:
There is growing evidence that e-cigarette use or vaping can harm lung health. The coronavirus attacks the lungs, making it harder for people who smoke or vape â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â to fight off the virus, putting them at much greater risk of severe illness, even death.
802Quits is the Vermont tobacco quit resource. You can get help to quit by phone or online.
By phone, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for 1:1 coaching, available 24/7, with email and text support.
Online: 802Quits.org
By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home right now.

question: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
answer:
Some early news reports suggested that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, could worsen coronavirus disease. However, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has said it is not aware of any scientific evidence connecting the use of NSAIDs with worsening COVID-19 symptoms at this time. The FDA is investigating this issue further.
There are multiple medicines you can buy with or without a doctorâs prescription that are approved for pain relief and fever reduction. Please read warning labels on all medications before using them and consult with your health care provider about what is best for you.

question: What is the Health Department doing about long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities?
answer:
The Heath Department is contacting all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.
If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.

question: What is Vermont doing?
answer:
On April 10, Governor Phil Scott extended Vermontâs State of Emergency through May 15 to help ensure Vermont has all the necessary resources to respond to this evolving threat. Find details on all executive orders.
The strategies continue to be updated based on guidance from federal and state public health officials. Find a summary of current strategies on the Governor's website.

question: Can ticks or mosquitoes spread the COVID-19 virus?
answer:
At this time, the CDC has no data to suggest that the COVID-19 virus or other similar coronaviruses are spread by mosquitoes or ticks. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.
Learn how to prevent mosquito bites and how to prevent tick bites.

question: What should I do if I need to see a dentist?
answer:
Dentists can now perform all dental procedures again, including those that generate aerosol. The dental community is confident it has the necessary knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to safely provide care.
Contact your dentist to find out if you can be seen. If you donât have a regular dentist and need help finding one, call 211.
Do not delay care if you have:

Heavy bleeding that wonât stop
Painful swelling in or around your mouth
Pain in a tooth, teeth or jawbone
Gum infection with pain or swelling
Treatment after surgery (dressing change, stitch removal)
Broken or knocked out tooth
Denture adjustment for people receiving radiation or other treatment for cancer
Wire of braces poking your cheek or gums
Biopsy of abnormal tissue

question: Are there any translated materials about COVID-19?
answer:
There is information about COVID-19 available in several languages from NewAmericansInVermont.com.
Find more information and translated materials from the Health Department.

question: Can I get tested with a swab in the front of my nose?
answer:
There is a test available that uses a dry swab to collect a sample from the front of your nose. At this time, the supplies needed for this type of test are limited. This type of test is being prioritized for different groups of people who may not be able to tolerate the longer nose swab (nasopharyngeal or NP) that collects samples from the back of the nose and throat. This includes children, patients at risk of increased bleeding or complications, patients with nasal irregularities (for example, polyps, deviated septum), people who need regular and repeated testing (for example, employees or residents of skilled nursing facilities), and those without the cognitive ability to understand the testing procedure.
Your health care provider will determine if you should be referred for this type of test. Please note the pop-up testing sites use the longer NP swabs.

question: What should businesses do to protect workers and customers?
answer:
Current information is on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others. Businesses may require customers to wear cloth face masks or coverings.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

More resources are available from the Health Department:

COVID-19 Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses
Health resources for businesses and food and lodging businesses
COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and Best Practices for Retail Food Stores, Restaurants, and Food Pick-Up/Delivery Services During the COVID-19 Pandemic from the FDA.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Are campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts open?
answer:
Lodging facilities â hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts, inns, short-term rentals (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), and all public and private camping facilities, RV parks, seasonal resorts and marinas â may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents, those who have met the quarantine requirement, and essential workers.
Find details and up-to-date information on lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD) ) and find information about traveling to Vermont from the Health Department.
All guests must complete a health questionnaire upon check-in and must provide a Vermont driverâs license or signed document certifying that they met the quarantine and travel requirements. Out-of-state guests are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert â a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19 â for daily reminders from the Vermont Department of Health.
If an individual has concerns about lodging facilities that are violating the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order, the Department of Public Safety has created an online non-compliance complaint form to gather more information.

question: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answer:
The challenge with dentistry is the generation of aerosols as part of many office-based activities. This includes dental hygiene through a variety of preventive, restorative, endodontic, periodontic and orthodontic procedures.
Dentists can now resume all procedures, including those that generate aerosol.Â Read the Interim Guidance for Resuming Dental Services in Vermont.
The dental community is confident it has the existing knowledge, skills, office processes and equipment, testing protocols, and personal protective equipment (PPE) to accomplish these safely. They will share the efforts and practices they have adopted with their patients.
Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

question: What should businesses and non-profits do?
answer:
Vermont is starting a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back. Businesses deemed âessentialâ may continue to operate under pre-existing
guidance, with the addition of the mandatory health and safety
requirements.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on their COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:


A step-by-step reopening guide for businesses


Up-to-date sector-specific guidance


Mandatory health and safety requirements. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others. Businesses and non-profits may require customers or clients to wear masks.


Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses


Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses from the Health Department.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Are summer camps and residential summer college programs happening?
answer:
Summer day camps serving Vermonters and those meeting the 14-day quarantine requirements, overnight summer camps, and limited residential summer college programs may operate under the Health Guidance for Childcare Programs and Summer Programs.
Find information on the mandatory health and safety requirements for overnight camps and residential summer college programs, including quarantine requirements for out-of-state staff and campers, guidance for families dropping off campers, and wearing cloth face masks or coverings around other people, from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Find more information about what parents can expect from child care and school age camps and care from the Vermont Department of Health.

question: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answer:
Starting June 19, facilities may offer limited visitation outside with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit.
Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.
The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.
Any new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.
Senior Centers may reopen with guidance from the Health Department and the Department of Aging and Independent Living. Adult Day programs remain closed.
There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.
Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.

question: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
answer:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, we know that many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.
MIS-C is rare, and it remains unknown whether multisystem inflammatory syndrome only occurs in children or if it also can occur in adults.
Learn more about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Health.

question: What do employers need to do to reopen their business?
answer:
All businesses must follow mandatory health and safety requirements as they reopen.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has the resources businesses need on their COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses, including a step-by-step reopening guide for businesses and sector-specific guidance.
Stagnant water in plumbing systems can lead to illness or cause disease. As offices, retail businesses, gyms and other buildings begin to reopen, they should follow state guidance and recommendations before using the drinking water again. Read the CDCâs Guidance for Reopening Buildings After Prolonged Shutdown or Reduced Operation for more information.

question: Can pets get sick from COVID-19?
answer:
We are still learning about the virus that causes COVID-19, but it appears that it can spread from people to animals in some situations.
There have been a few confirmed cases of animals infected with COVID-19:

a tiger at a zoo in New York
two pet cats in New York
a cat in Minnesota
aÂ dog in New York

The CDC recommends the following:
Until we learn more about how this virus affects animals, treat pets as you would other human family members to protect them from a possible infection.
Because there is a small risk that people with COVID-19 could spread the virus to animals, CDC recommends that pet owners limit their petâs interaction with people outside their household.

Keep cats indoors when possible and do not let them roam freely outside.
Walk dogs on a leash at least 6 feet away from others.
Avoid public places where large numbers of people gather.
Do not put face coverings on pets. Covering a petâs face could harm them.

Talk to your veterinarian if your pet gets sick or if you have any concerns about your petâs health.
Learn more about what to do if you have pets and answers to frequently asked questions about COVID-19 and animals from the CDC.
Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

question: Are bars and restaurants open?
answer:
Restaurants may offer outdoor dining service under certain conditions. Bars, breweries, distilleries, cideries, and tasting rooms may also offer outdoor dining and beverage service under certain health and safety requirements.
Limited indoor dining at restaurants and bars is allowed.
Establishments can continue to offer food takeout and delivery.
Find more details and up-to-date information about bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

question: Is the state reopened?
answer:
Vermont has begun a phased approach to reopen the economy, balancing overall social and economic wellbeing with preventing a rise in COVID-19 that would set us back.
Current information for businesses, non-profit and government operations that are open and their health and safety requirements under the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order is available from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Businesses can find a step-by-step guide to reopening and up-to-date sector-specific guidance from the ACCD.
Find the most recent Governorâs Executive Orders for more information.

question: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answer:
Lodging operations, short-term rentals, campgrounds and marinas may accept overnight reservations from Vermont residents, those who have met the quarantine requirement, and essential workers under mandatory health and safety requirements.
Lodging operators should recommend that all out-of-state guests sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. Guests from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine. They have the option to quarantine at a lodging facility for 14 days if they make stops along the way or travel by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.
Find details on the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses:

Up-to-date guidance for lodging and accommodations and for campgrounds, RV parks, and seasonal resorts. This includes having a health safety officer onsite at every shift and requiring employees to wear face coverings over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.
Answers to Be Smart, Stay Safe FAQs for Businesses

Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses from the Health Department.
The Vermont State Police and local law enforcement will monitor lodging providers for compliance and work with the Attorney Generalâs Office on additional compliance measures if needed. Learn about guidance on enforcement of the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order from the Vermont Department of Public Safety.
The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.

question: Are outpatient services open?
answer:
Outpatient services are reopened for professions licensed by the Office of Professional Regulation.
Those professions that provide care without physical contact or with some physical contact Â may resume outpatient services â such as licensed alcohol and drug counselors (LADACs), Allied Mental Health, dieticians, psychologists, social workers, acupuncturists, chiropractors, physical therapists, occupational therapists, opticians and optometrists.
For those professions involved in care that is more likely to expose them to the COVID-19 virus â such as doctors of osteopathy, naturopathy, physician assistants, and nurses â outpatient clinic visits and diagnostic imaging may resume.

question: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answer:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may appear 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4 Â°F or greater) or chills
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Call your health care provider if you are having symptoms. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.
Learn more about COVID-19.

question: What if Iâve had contact with someone who is under monitoring?
answer: If you have been in a home or in close contact with a person who is under monitoring, you do not need to take any additional steps â as long as you are not experiencing COVID-19 symptoms.

question: Do I need to quarantine if out-of-state visitors are staying in my home?
answer:
If you are hosting travelers under quarantine in your home or lodging, you do not also need to quarantine. If you are sharing space, stay at least 6 feet from the people under quarantine. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Disinfect commonly touched surfaces and check for symptoms for 14 days.
Visitors from counties in New York and New England with low numbers of active infections do not need to quarantine. Read the travel guidance and check the map of approved counties, which is updated weekly.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for information for travelers to Vermont. They can get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answer:
Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.
Quarantine is for people with no symptoms who are returning to Vermont from out of state or who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19. This helps prevent spread of disease before a person knows they are sick or if they are infected with the virus without feeling symptoms.
Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days before doing any activities outside of the home, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms. Sign up for daily symptom check reminders.
Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.
Find more information on the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
Check the latest quarantine guidance for people visiting or returning to Vermont.

question: What does the Stay Home, Stay Safe Order mean for Vermonters?
answer:
Under the Governorâs executive order extension â Be Smart, Stay Safe â Vermonters are encouraged to limit their exposure to the COVID-19 virus outside their homes as much as possible.
Vermonters should travel only as needed:

For personal safety, medical care and care of others
For work, although all workers should continue to work remotely whenever possible
For shopping and services available at all businesses and non-profit and government entities determined to be critical and those which have been authorized to resume operations
To get fresh air and exercise by taking advantage of outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities that require low or no direct physical contact
For limited social interactions and gatherings of 25 or fewer, preferably in outdoor settings
For in-state stays at available lodging, campground and marina facilities

Vermonters should follow health and safety precautions to help keep the virus from spreading by:

Staying home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.
Keeping a physical distance of at least 6 feet away from others (except for those you live with).
Washing or sanitizing your hands often.
Wearing a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when a physical distance of at least 6 feet is difficult to maintain (for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path).
Coughing and sneezing into your elbow (even when wearing a face covering).
Limiting travel to within Vermont to the extent possible and when you do travel, limit non-essential stops.

Older adults (age 65 and over), and people with underlying medical conditions, like heart and lung disease or diabetes, are more likely to develop severe illness. They should take extra precautions.
Learn how to safely connect with friends and family. These recommended practices will help you weigh the risk and plan accordingly.
Read the latest updates to the Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development has resources for individuals and sector-specific guidance for details on which businesses are open.

question: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answer:
Justices of the peace and other officiants may perform in-person marriages if there are 25 or fewer people. Town offices may decide to issue marriage licenses.
Ceremonies should preferably be outside, while keeping a 6-foot distance from others, and wearing cloth face masks or coverings.
If you are visiting Vermont you may need to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find up-to-date information on marriage ceremonies from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development

question: Can I use reusable grocery bags?
answer:
Yes, people can continue to use reusable grocery bags. However, some stores are choosing to no longer allow reusable bags and containers at this time. Check with your local store for their current policies.
After July 1, stores and food service establishments will no longer provide plastic bags at check-out. Youâll have the option to purchase paper bags for 10 cents each or use reusable bags. If a store has temporarily banned reusable bags, consider putting your groceries back into your cart and bag them at your car. Some stores and food establishments may still offer plastic bags after July 1 since they are allowed to use the ones they currently have in stock until they are gone.
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. It is important to remember to wash your hands before you eat and to avoid touching your face.
Make sure you clean your reusable bags regularly, which can also help prevent illnesses from bacteria, such as E.coli, that are from meat and unwashed fruits and vegetables.
Find more information and tips about the single-use plastics ban from the Department of Environmental Conservation.

question: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
answer:
The COVID-19 virus could possibly enter waterways through untreated wastewater that is discharged into waterways following large rain events or for other reasons. The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, but there has been no evidence that a person can get COVID-19 from being exposed to untreated wastewater or sewerage systems.
According to the CDC, it is thought that the COVID-19 virus does not spread through standard municipal and individual septic system wastewater treatment practices. Guidance will be updated if anything new is learned.
The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large storm events during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.
The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rain events, and do not swallow the water.

question: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
answer:
People who have trouble breathing can wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom or a face shield. Face shields are generally not recommended because they are more for health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in. However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a cloth face mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier on your nose and mouth.
Outdoor workers who are doing strenuous work that causes heavy breathing are not required to wear a cloth face mask or covering when it is hot outside. Workers should keep masks with them and wear them when they are not exerting themselves (for example talking, resting, or interacting with other co-workers or people). It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.

question: Where can I buy cloth face masks or coverings?
answer:
The Department of Public Safety has a list of where to buy face coverings from businesses.
You can also reach out to your community. Check out places like Front Porch Forum to connect with other Vermonters making cloth face masks or coverings.

question: Do I need to quarantine if I do a short trip (day trip)?
answer:
People who live near the Vermont border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state may make day trips to VermontÂ for work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody without quarantining.
If you go on a day trip that is not in an approved county with low rates of active cases, you must quarantine in Vermont upon return.

question: How can I safely run errands for essential purposes?
answer: The CDC has guidance on how to safely run essential errands to meet basic household needs, such as going grocery shopping, getting deliveries and take-out, banking, and getting gas.

question: Is it safe to go grocery shopping?
answer:
Currently there is no evidence to show that the COVID-19 virus is spread through food or food packaging. Follow these tips to stay safe while you shop:

Stay home if you are sick. Ask a family member, friend or neighbor to help you get your groceries, or see about having food delivered.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering while youâre in the store.
Keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible. Follow any arrows on the floor or other signage that directs how people should move through the store.
When you leave the store, wash your hands or use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

The Vermont Retail & Grocers Association has a regularly updated list of what services Vermont retailers and grocers are offering during the COVID-19 pandemic. These services range from limited delivery, to curbside pickup and designated shopping hours for vulnerable populations.
Read more about shopping for food during the COVID-19 pandemic guidance from the Food and Drug Administration.

question: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answer:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. Here is how you can protect yourself from COVID-19, and avoid spreading it to others:

Stay at home to protect others if you are sick.
Keep gatherings small and have them outside whenever possible.
When you leave home, stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when you cannot keep a 6-foot distance from other people, for example, at a grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path. Masks may be required in some places like on public transportation.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash. Then immediately wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, going to the bathroom, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Always wash hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remote controllers, handles, desks, toilets, sinks) using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe
Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19. Check the guidance for people traveling to Vermont, and read CDC's guidance on travel in the United States.

Learn more about COVID-19 prevention and how to protect yourself and others.

question: What does social distancing mean?
answer:
Social distancing means maintaining a physical distance (approximately 6 feet or 2 meters) from people you do not live with. This includes when youâre inside a store, gathering with friends or family, or outside for exercise or a walk.
The COVID-19 virus spreads easily from person-to-person. It travels through the air from respiratory droplets released when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. A person can be infected and not have any symptoms. In addition to keeping a 6-foot distance from others, everyone should:

Stay home to protect others if you are sick.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering in public settings when you cannot keep a 6-foot distance from other people, for example, at the grocery store or on a crowded sidewalk or bike path.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after being in a public place, going to the bathroom, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Keep groups small when you can to limit any possible exposure, and follow health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Iâm young. Can I continue to socialize?
answer:
Whatever your age, staying home is still the best way to lower our risk of COVID-19, but many of us are eager to take small steps to safely see our friends and family again. Groups of 25 or fewer people are allowed to gather if health and safety precautions are followed. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Even though the risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions, young people can also get sick. The virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms. Taking health and safety precautions protects everyone and helps slow the spread of this virus. Everyone should wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

question: Can the COVID-19 virus spread through pools and hot tubs?
answer:
There is no evidence that the virus can spread to people through the use of pools, hot tubs or water playgrounds. Proper operation and disinfection of the water (for example, with chlorine and bromine) should kill the virus.
Everyone should follow these general precautions to help prevent the COVID-19 virus from spreading: wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre not in the water, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.
Find more more frequently asked questions about COVID-19 and water from the CDC.

question: What should returning and new college students do?
answer:
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Students from certain approved counties with low rates of active cases do not need to quarantine.
All students are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once arriving in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
College students returning to Burlington can also use the cityâs Supportive Quarantine Pilot Program. The program includes a move-in care package of fresh local goods, a mask, and hygiene supplies.

question: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answer:
According to the CDC, risk for severe illness from COVID-19 increases with age, with older adults at highest risk. People of any age with certain underlying medical conditions are also at increased risk for severe illness. In addition to the general COVID-19 prevention steps, these groups should consider limiting their risk:

Stay close to home as much as possible. Traveling out of state is not recommended since the virus is still widespread in neighboring states and across the country.
Be aware of your surroundings. Choose outdoor settings over indoor settings. Pay attention to the size of the space, crowding, the number of people there, and if they are wearing face coverings and keeping a 6-foot distance.
Choose activities that donât require close contact. Minimize close contact while talking or doing anything that requires exertion, shouting or singing.
Keep your social circle small. Choose a few other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions.

The CDC recommends other populations also take extra precautions, like pregnant people, people experiencing homelessness, and people with disabilities.

question: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
answer:
Event venues, arts, culture and entertainment venues, and restaurants can hold events, such as weddings, funerals and parties, with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions. Outdoor services, events, and gatherings are strongly preferred.
All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.
Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).
Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.
Libraries, galleries, museums, theaters and other indoor arts, culture and entertainment organizations are open with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions.
Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
At any gathering or event, everyone should follow these general precautions: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.

question: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answer:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.
Follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and community:

Stay home except to get medical care.
Separate yourself from other people.
Monitor your symptoms.
Call ahead before visiting your doctor.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes.
Wash your hands often.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces daily.

Find more details on what to do if you are sick from the CDC.

question: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
answer:
Based on what we know at this time,Â pregnant peopleÂ might be at an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19Â compared to non-pregnant people. Additionally, there may be an increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as preterm birth, among pregnant people with COVID-19. Therefore, if you are pregnant, be mindful about reducing your risk of getting sick.
Learn more from CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.
Find more resources for families with children.

question: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
answer:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself.
With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available would not produce results that are accurate or reliable enough in Vermont. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
Though certain providers may offer antibody testing in Vermont, the working group cautions against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals, for example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

question: Where can I get food assistance?
answer: There are multiple options for those in need to get help, including meal distribution and other food resources. Get more details on how to get food help.

question: What should colleges and universities in Vermont do?
answer:
Colleges and universities must follow the Mandatory Guidance for College and University Campus Learning published by the Agency of Commerce and Community Development, the Heath Department, and the Vermont Department of Public Safety.
Find more information and guidance for schools from the Health Department.

question: How does COVID-19 spread?
answer:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Another person can become infected if the droplets land in their mouth or nose and possibly if the droplets are inhaled into the lungs. The virus might also spread to a personâs hands from a contaminated surface and then to their nose, mouth, or possibly their eyes. Not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms.
There is growing scientific evidence that smaller particles of the COVID-19 virus in the air indoors can infect people. These lighter, finer droplets â that we allÂ exhale from coughing or talking â may stay in the airÂ for several hours, especially when thereâs poor ventilation or overcrowding.
You could become infected if you have indoor contact with those aerosols for an extended period of time.
Follow these general precautions to help prevent the virus from spreading:

Wear a cloth face mask or covering
Keep a 6-foot distance from others
Wash your hands often
Stay home if you are sick.

Learn more from the CDC about how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

question: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answer:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number people who are currently infected with COVID-19.
However, it is important to remember that not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms and there are still many people who are currently infected and could spread it to others.
Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:

Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days
A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care
The ability to test all people with symptoms
Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts

At this time, Vermont continues to do well in keeping the number of cases of COVID-19 down. This is hopeful news. To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue to follow the general precautions to keep the virus from spreading and to help save lives: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.
Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

question: Can I get together with friends and family?
answer:
Vermonters can get together with friends and family, but should keep groups small whenever possible to limit any possible exposure, and follow health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance of following the general precautions in their day-to-day lives: wearing a cloth face mask or covering, keeping a 6-foot distance from others, washing their hands often, and staying home if they are sick.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of the virus. .
To keep COVID-19 from spreading, we must continue to:

Wear a cloth face mask or covering over your nose and mouth.
Stay home and away from others if you are sick with COVID-19, have recently been exposed to someone who has COVID-19, or just donât feel well.
Keep a 6-foot distance from others when you meet people outside of your household.
Wash your hands frequently (use hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol when soap and water are not available).
Cough and sneeze into your elbow (even if you are wearing a cloth face mask or covering).
Limiting travel to within Vermont to the extent possible and when you do travel, limit non-essential stops.

The risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. They should stay close to home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.

question: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answer:
Usually a health care provider collects samples (specimens) from you in one of two ways, but there are other options:

The health care provider collects a nasal, or nasopharyngeal (NP) swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.
The health care provider collects a sample from the front of your nose with a dry swab.

question: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
answer:
You can find the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. This map is updated daily.
Below the data dashboard, there is a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.
When looking at the county numbers, please remember that low or no recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter what county we live in or visit. The map reflects the number of people who had a positive test. There may be active cases in your county that havenât been tested.
A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

question: What is an antigen test?
answer:
An antigen test for COVID-19 is a newer type test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus. According to the CDC and the Association of Public Health Laboratories, antigen tests are only recommended for people who have symptoms of COVID-19. So far, studies on antigen tests have only been done on people with symptoms, and we do not have evidence about the accuracy of the antigen test on people without symptoms. More studies are required before antigen testing can be recommended for people without symptoms of COVID-19.
Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than PCR tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose and confirm COVID-19 infection). When used appropriately to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, antigen tests have a higher chance of missing an active infection than PCR tests. This means that if you have symptoms, you may receive a negative result but still be infected with COVID-19.
Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test.
We are monitoring how these antigen tests evolve and how results can best be used. Right now, people who test positive from antigen tests are not considered to have a lab-confirmed case of COVID-19 and are not included in our total number of cases. However, we consider these cases âpresumptive positivesâ and recommend they follow the same guidelines as a positive case to stay home (self-isolate). We also conduct contact tracing and recommend a PCR test to confirm the positive result.
Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the coronavirus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
Learn more:

Coronavirus testing basics from the Food & Drug Administration
Considerations for Implementation of SARS-CoV-2 Rapid Antigen Testing from the Association of Public Health Laboratories.

question: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
answer: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.

question: Are there any travel restrictions if I am traveling through Vermont?
answer: If you are only traveling through and not staying in Vermont (for example, driving through Vermont to another state, flying to Vermont and immediately picking up a rental car to drive to another state), there are no quarantine or other restrictions you need to follow. If you need to make stops in Vermont or are otherwise not in a vehicle while you are traveling through Vermont, please follow these general precautions to help prevent the spread of the virus: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often.

question: Are there any travel restrictions into Vermont? Are out-of-state visitors allowed?
answer:
If you are visiting or returning to Vermont you may need to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you are coming from certain approved counties with low rates of active cases, you do not need to quarantine
All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle OR
Quarantine at a lodging facility or Vermont home for 14 days if you are traveling by plane, train, bus or other means of transportation.

You have the option to get tested on Day 7 of your quarantine. Learn more under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when necessary. When you stop, follow the general precautions: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: What is a PCR test?
answer:
A PCR test is the most common type of COVID-19 test used today. PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction. The test identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.
PCR tests are generally the most reliable tests. Samples are analyzed at a lab, which usually takes up to a few days. A PCR test is used at pop-up testing sites offered by the Health Department.
Data on COVID-19 activity reported by the Health Department includes only PCR tests.
The PCR test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.

question: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answer:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. However, a few children have developed multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.
You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to do the same things everyone should do to stay healthy.

Stay home if you are sick and avoid people who are sick.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering.
Keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household.
Wash hands often using soap and water (or hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol).
Socialize with household members or other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions.
Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks).
Wash items including washable plush toys, according to the manufacturerâs instructions. If possible, wash items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from a person who is sick can be washed with other peopleâs items.

Vermonters can get together with friends and family, but are encouraged to keep groups small when possible to limit any possible exposure to the virus and to keep it from spreading and to follow health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC on caring for young children.

question: How can I get help finding a health care provider?
answer:
Vermont 2-1-1 listsÂ community clinics and hospital-connected clinics around the state and can connect you with one if you do not have a health care provider.
Vermont 2-1-1 does not list individual primary care providers. If you need a health care provider referral, contact your health care insurer.

question: Are there resources available to help with home schooling?
answer:
There is programming available from a partnership with the Agency of Education and Vermont PBS for PreK through 12th grade that is aligned to national â and customized to Vermont â standards. The programming includes interactive lessons and paired suggested activities for educators, students and families. There are also resources available that allow teachers and caregivers to access at-home curriculum that includes activities, assignments and learning objectives.
Find the programming schedule and resources for educators, parents and caregivers from Vermont PBS. It is available on all cable systems and for free over the air through a digital antenna without the need for cable subscription or broadband internet access.
Find additional strategies and resources for educators and families from the Agency of Education.

question: What do I do if one of my co-workersÂ has COVID-19?
answer: Learning that a co-worker has tested positive for COVID-19 can be stressful, but there are actions you can take to stay safe. ReadÂ what to do when your co-worker has COVID-19.

question: How can children socialize while still preventing the spread of COVID-19?
answer:
When children are socializing, itâs best for them to keep at least 6 feet away from people they do not live with and to avoid places where they may be close to other people. Itâs also important for parents â and children over 2 who are able â to wear cloth face masks or coverings when youâre around people you do not live with. Learn more about face coverings for children.
If you choose to socialize with family, friends and neighbors, choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions and keep groups small whenever possible. A trusted household is one that has taken seriously the importance following these general precautions in their day-to-day lives: wearing cloth face masks or coverings, keeping a 6-foot distance from others, washing their hands often, and staying home if they are sick.
Choose outdoor activities where itâs easy to maintain a 6-foot distance. Remember that ticks are active this time of year. Learn how to Be Tick Smart and prevent tick bites.
Continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family who you are not meeting up with in person. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.
