Most people who get sick from COVID-19 â including children â will experience mild symptoms and recover, but following the general precautions will help us limit the virusâs spread to our vulnerable populations.
Find more resources for families with children.

question: Is there a rapid (fast) test for COVID-19?
answer: There are a few different types of COVID-19 tests, and some are faster than others. The tests also look for different information. If you think you need to be tested for COVID-19, talk with your health care provider about what testing might be appropriate. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic. Get more information about the COVID-19 tests that are currently available from the Food and Drug Administration.

question: Is it okay to travel within the United States? Do I need to quarantine when I return?
answer:
COVID-19 cases and deaths have been reported in all 50 states, and the situation is constantly changing. Travel increases your chances of getting and spreading COVID-19. According to the CDC, staying home is the best way to protect yourself and others from getting sick. Donât travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick. Read the CDCâs considerations for travelers if you are thinking of traveling away from your local community.
Vermonters may travel toÂ certain counties with low rates of active cases. If you make your trip in a personal vehicle, you do not need to quarantine upon return to Vermont.Â If you travel out of state to a location other than thoseÂ counties with low rates of active cases, you must quarantine in VermontÂ forÂ 14 daysÂ upon return. This includes day trips.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested with a PCR test. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do when you return to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.

question: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
answer:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).
Face masks or coverings are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

Children under the age of 2
Anyone who has trouble breathing
Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.
Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who do not to wear a mask.
Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.
In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.
Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.

question: Do I need a negative COVID-19 test result to return to work safely?
answer:
A negative test for COVID-19 should NOT be required to return to work. The Health Department does not issue letters for employees to return to work either.
The best way to know when itâs safe for someone who tested positive for COVID-19 to return to work is to follow guidance based on the presence of symptoms, or the amount of time that has passed since the person was tested. This information is found in the employer guidance, under âWhen can employees with COVID-19 return to work?â

question: How can I make my own homemade cloth face mask or covering?
answer:
Homemade cloth face masks or coverings can be made using simple materials found in most homes, for example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Your cloth face mask or covering should include multiple layers of fabric and allow you to be able to breathe easily. Watch a quick video by the CDC on how to make your own cloth face mask.
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).
Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.

question: I traveled internationally or by cruise ship. Do I or my household members need to quarantine?
answer:
If youâve returned from international travel or from a cruise ship or river cruise voyage, you must quarantine for 14 days. Other members of your household who did not travel do not need to quarantine, but should observe themselves for symptoms for 14 days. Learn about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.
If you or your household members develop symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider right away. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected with a local community or hospital-connected clinic.
Check the Health Departmentâs webpage for what to do if you are visiting or returning to Vermont. Get the latest travel and quarantine guidance, sign up to get daily symptom check reminders by email, text or phone, learn about testing options during quarantine, and find out how to safely connect with friends and family.
Find more information from the CDC about returning from international travel and returning from cruise ship and river cruise voyages.
Stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 travel advisories from the CDC.

question: Do I need to quarantine if someone I had close contact with is under quarantine?
answer:
No. You do not need to quarantine if you had close contact with someone who is under quarantine.
If you are living with someone who is under quarantine, stay at least 6 feet from them. People under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

question: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answer:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:
If you had symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after these three things have happened (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider:

you have had no fever for at least 24 hours without the use medicine that reduces fevers AND
other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND
at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you did not have any symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after:

10 days have passed since the date you had your positive test (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider).

Your health care provider will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
After stopping home isolation, continue to follow the general precautions to help keep the virus from spreading:Â wear aÂ cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others you donât live with, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

question: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
answer:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).
Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.
In addition to wearing cloth face masks or coverings, everyone should keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.
A face mask or covering must be worn properly to be effective and avoid the spread of germs:

Wash your hands before putting it on.
Be sure your mouth and nose are covered.
Hook loops around your ears or tie it snugly.
Do not touch it or pull it down while in public.
Keep it on until you get home.
Remove it without touching your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately.
Wash it and make sure itâs completely dry before using again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate for washing.

If you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot outside, you should take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.
Learn more about using cloth face masks or coverings to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and face coverings for children.

question: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answer:
We encourage Vermonters to go outside and enjoy the fresh air. Exercise, outdoor activities, and taking in Vermontâs natural beauty are important for our minds and bodies. As you enjoy the outdoors, be sure to follow these summer safety tips.
Businesses, non-profit and government entities that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities with low or no direct physical contact are open under certain health and safety requirements. These include, but are not limited to, state parks, municipal parks, recreation associations, pools, beaches, play structures or playgrounds, trail networks, golf courses, big game check stations and guided expeditions.
Find up-to-date information on outdoor recreation and campgrounds from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Sports with no contact or low contact and team sports are allowed with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions. Whenever possible, players, coaches, officials, staff and spectators need to keep a 6-foot distance from each other and wear face masks or coverings whenever it is not possible to keep that distance. Find up-to-date information on sports and organized sports from the ACCD.
We can safely continue to enjoy outdoor activities with these measures:

Stay close to home. Find local outdoor recreation areas and consider day trips that are close to home. Only drive with members of your household.
Take health and safety precautions. Keep the virus from spreading by staying at least 6 feet apart from other people outside of your household, washing or sanitizing your hands, and staying home when you are sick.
Bring a cloth face mask or covering with you. You are required to put on a face mask or covering if you are not able to keep a 6-foot distance from people you donât live with.
Be cautious and choose low-risk activities to avoid injury. This will help lower the burden on our hospitals and health care system.
Respect signs for closed areas, trails and land. Check Trail Finder to see if your trail is currently open before you visit. Call ahead or check websites for information on outdoor recreation facilities before you head out.
Choose low- or no-contact sports, for example, biking, hiking, horseback riding, tennis, boating and golfing. Outdoor basketball courts may be open to shoot hoops, but signage should be posted prohibiting contact games. Do not share sports equipment with people outside of your household.
Check for ticks and wear an EPA-registered tick repellent. When youâre out walking or spending time in your backyard, remember that ticks are active this time of year. Find out how to Be Tick Smart prevent tick bites.

Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department. Please note that there have been a lot of visitors at some state parks. If you experience overcrowding at a state park, please email parks@vermont.gov or find more information on Vermont State Parks COVID-19 updates.
Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.
Read the CDCâs frequently asked questions about youth sports programs.

question: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answer:
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested. The test must be a PCR test. Talk to your health care provider to find out where to get tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care.
For travelers who are completing quarantine in their home state, your home state may offer testing for people without symptoms. Continue to quarantine from when you receive your test result until you travel to Vermont.
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on Day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back; AND
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms.

For anyone coming into Vermont, Day 1 is the day after you arrive in Vermont.
However, if you end your quarantine period before 14 days, you must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days. If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1. Sign up to receive daily symptom check reminders.
If you are a close contact of someone who tested positive for COVID-19, see scenarios from the CDC to determine when you can end quarantine and be around others.
Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This is why there is the option for people to be tested on Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
New admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.

question: Is it safe to send my children back to school or child care?
answer:
Yes, based on current data and levels of the COVID-19 virus in Vermont, it is safe â and important â for children to go to school or child care for in-person learning. On July 27, the Vermont Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics asked schools to prioritize in-person attendance for preschool to grade 5, and for students with special needs.
We know much more about the virus now than we did in March when schools closed for the spring. The Health Department can track data in real time and respond to cases quickly with our contact tracing teams. We also have robust testing and contact tracing system in Vermont that will support schools in containing the virus if there is a case.
Children need structure, relationships with their peers, teachers, and other adults for their academic, social, and emotional development. Although remote learning is an important tool during the pandemic, it can lead to even greater gaps in equity. Public health and education experts considered all these factors when writing Vermontâs guidance to reopen schools, which focuses on the safety of teachers, staff, and students.
We are seeing more cases of COVID-19 in children nationwide and in Vermont, but that is not surprising as states have reopened, and more testing has become available.
We recognize there may be cases in schools as they reopen. This is why Vermontâs reopening guidance outlines ways to keep the virus out of schools and prevent it from spreading through physical distancing, face masks or coverings, hand hygiene, and contact tracing.

question: Do homemade cloth face masks or coverings work?
answer:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks) and group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes).
In private settings with people you donât live with (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering when itâs not possible to stay 6 feet apart.
Wearing a homemade cloth face mask or covering can offer some protection to others. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms. The cloth face mask or covering can contain respiratory droplets and prevent them from spreading to others.
Learn more about wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading and face coverings for children.

question: Can I wear a face shield instead of a face mask or covering?
answer:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household. In private settings with people you donât live with, we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering when itâs not possible to stay 6 feet apart. However, for some people, and in some cases, a face shield may be an option.
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.
If you have trouble breathing or if you work in a setting where it is difficult to wear a face mask or covering, wearing a face shield is better than wearing nothing over your nose and mouth. People who have trouble breathing can also wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom. In school settings, students and adults are allowed to wear face shields, and in child care settings, providers, teachers and staff are allowed to wear face shields.
Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like face masks or coverings when putting them on or removing them. (see âWhat is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?â on this page for more details).

question: Can I buy or sign a long-term lease (more than 30 days) for a new apartment or house?
answer:
Long-term rental leases are allowed. Moving and moving services are also allowed, as long as people keep a 6-foot distance from each other. Wearing a face mask or covering is required whenever it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with. More housing information is available at the Agency of Commerce and Community Development's (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.
Real estate services, including real estate firms, brokerages, attorneys or individuals, must work remotely as much as possible to minimize in-person contact. Real estate and related services (such as title searches, appraisals, and home inspections) are operating under certain health and safety requirements including keeping at least 6 feet away from others and wearing face masks or coverings.
Out-of-state buyers and renters must follow all quarantine requirements.
Find details and up-to-date information on real estate from the ACCD.

question: What does close contact mean?
answer:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for 15 minutes or more, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people who didn't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they are recovered.
Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a short period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.
Here are some examples:
Examples of close contacts:

You live in the same home.
You are intimate partners.
You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.
You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

You were their cashier at the grocery store.
You were their server at a restaurant.
You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.
You were in front of the person in line at the store.
You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. If the Health Department determines that you were a close contact of the person who tested positive, then the Health Department will call you to tell you what you need to do.
As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with
each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch
with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

question: What is Sara Alert?
answer:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. PeopleÂ visiting or returning to VermontÂ are strongly encouraged to sign up to get dailyÂ reminders byÂ email, text or phoneÂ askingÂ if they are experiencing anyÂ symptoms.
Sara Alert sends daily reminders until they automatically stop after two weeks since the day you report arriving in Vermont. If you are going to be in Vermont for at least two weeks, itâs important to stay enrolled for the entire monitoring period to help our public health response to COVID-19.
If symptoms are reported, a member of our team will reach out to provide guidance and next steps. Sara Alert isÂ **notÂ **a contact tracing system. It is not GPS-based, so it does not monitorÂ someone's movements or track their location.
Here are some reasons why you should sign up for Sara Alert:

You get fast, easy, and free reminders to check yourself for symptoms.
You get quick access to the Health Department for guidance and information if you develop symptoms.
It helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

If you are currently enrolled in Sara Alert and have questions about your messages, email the Travel Team at ahs.vdhcovid19returntravelerinquiries@vermont.gov or call 802-863-7240 (option 6).
Sign up for Sara Alert.

question: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answer:
When someone tests positive for COVID-19, the Health Department works with them to identify their close contacts. Generally, these are people you were within 6 feet of, for at least 15 minutes, during the time they were infectious (contagious).
If you are identified as a close contact, a contact tracer will call you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you are not identified as a close contact, then you will not be called. While contact tracers work to identify all close contacts, all might not be identified. If you think that you might be a close contact but didn't get a call from the Health Department, you may take precautions by quarantining for 14 days since the last day you were in contact with that person, and get tested on day 7 or after if you have not had any symptoms.
If you are not a close contact of a person who tested positive, you can continue to take the general precautions to slow the spread of the virus: keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with, wear a face mask or covering when you can't keep 6 feet apart, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.

question: What should schools and child care programs in Vermont do?
answer:
Schools will reopen on September 8. The Agency of Education and the Health Department created a guidance document for school administrators and personnel as they plan and implement the reopening of schools for the 2020-21 school year. Read A Strong and Healthy Start: Safety and Health Guidance for Reopening Schools, Fall 2020.
Find more COVID-19 guidance for Vermont schools from the Agency of Education.
Child care providers may also open, following health and safety precautions outlined in the Health Guidance for Childcare and School Age Camps/Care. Find answers to frequently asked questions about health and safety guidance for child care and summer programs.
Find more resources and information for schools and child care programs.

question: I have a second home or a seasonal home in Vermont. Can I come to Vermont?
answer:
If you are returning to your second or seasonal home in Vermont, you may be required to quarantine for 14 days before engaging in any activities, like grocery shopping or getting together with friends or family. Staying in and completing quarantine is extremely important to help keep people from spreading the virus when they may not know they have it. We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders. You must also follow the Governorâs Be Smart, Stay Safe Order.
If you are coming from certain approved counties with low rates of active cases, you do not need to quarantine.
All other travelers coming to Vermont must quarantine.
You can either:

Quarantine in your home state for 14 days before coming to Vermont if you are driving in your personal vehicle (including a rental vehicle or private plane) OR
Quarantine at a lodging facility or Vermont home for 14 days if you are traveling by [plane, train, bus or other means of transportation](((including a rental vehicle or private plane).

You have the option to get tested on Day 7 of your quarantine. Learn more under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Limit your stops when traveling to Vermont, and only stop when absolutely necessary for example, for fuel, food or rest). Try to plan your stops in an approved county. When you stop, follow the general precautions: keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with, wear a face mask or covering when you can't keep 6 feet apart, and wash your hands often. Stay home and do not travel if you are sick.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: Do I need to quarantine if I'm traveling for an essential purpose (like work in a neighboring state or parental shared custody)?
answer:
If you are traveling for essential purposes, you do not need to quarantine. Essential travel includes travel for personal safety, medical care, care of others, parental shared custody, for food, beverage or medicine, or for work.
If you live near a border and regularly travel to and from a neighboring state, you may make day trips to that state for work, health care, and other essential needs like groceries or visitation for parental shared custody, without quarantining.
However, if you come in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19, you should self-quarantine for 14 days, no matter where the contact occurred. Learn more about what to do if youâre a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
If you travel out of state for leisure and to a location that is not in an approved county with low rates of active cases, you must quarantine for 14 days in Vermont upon return. This includes day trips. Find up-to-date information about travel and COVID-19.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested with a PCR test. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: If I go on vacation, do I need to quarantine before I return to work?
answer:
If you travel to an approved county with a low rate of active infections, you do not need to quarantine.
If you travel to a county that is not approved, then you need to quarantine for 14 days, either before you come back to Vermont or upon your return to Vermont. This applies to both employees living in Vermont and employees who live in a neighboring state and commute to Vermont for work.
Anyone currently under quarantine who has had no symptoms during the first seven days of quarantine has the option to be tested with a PCR test. Find out how under âI am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?â on this page.
Your employer may provide sick or vacation time for you to complete your quarantine.

question: Where is it safe to travel internationally? Is it safe to go on a cruise ship or river cruise?
answer:
If you are planning on traveling internationally, check the current list of Travel Advisories by country from the U.S. Department of State, and visit travel.state.gov for detailed information on safe international travel.
You can also find the latest health guidance on international travel from the CDC, and read the FAQs for Travelers.
The CDC recommends no one travel on cruise ships, including river cruises, worldwide, especially people with an increased risk of serious illness. Thatâs because the risk of COVID-19 on cruise ships is high. Learn more about cruise ships and river cruise voyages.

question: How much does the test cost?
answer: There is no cost to individuals for a PCR test for COVID-19.

question: I need to drop off someone at college. Do I need to quarantine?
answer:
Yes. You have two options:

You follow the State of Vermontâs travel and quarantine requirements OR
You do the drop-off while under quarantine conditions.

Here are the quarantine conditions for option 2:

You must travel by personal vehicle to and from Vermont.
Do not enter any college facilities. You may help the student unload at the curb only.
Wear a face mask any time you are outside of your vehicle.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
If your drive is farther than a single day trip, you may stay at a lodging property only if you quarantine at that property for your entire stay. This means you must stay in the room or house and not leave to go to the grocery store, restaurants or any other places where you might come into contact with other people. You may not use lodging property amenities such as pools, spas, gyms, recreation equipment or other general use facilities.

We strongly encourage you contact the school before you travel to find out if there are any move-in restrictions or rules.

question: What is contact tracing?
answer:
Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.
If you test positive for COVID-19, you will get a call from the Health Department. A trained public health worker, called a contact tracer, will give you guidance to stay home and away from other people until you recover. This stops the virus from spreading to other people. They will ask you questions about your symptoms, activities, and who you may have come into contact with during a specific period of time. This information is only used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
If you are identified as a close contact,Â a contact tracer will call you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
Itâs important to answer any call from the Health DepartmentÂ and to answer questions as completely as possible to make sure everyone knows whatÂ steps to take to prevent further spread of the virus.
The Health Department only uses a live person forÂ contact tracingÂ and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call for this service.
As the state continues to reopen, consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

question: Do I need documentation to certify that I completed my quarantine or received a negative test result before I travel to Vermont?
answer:
If you are a visitor and staying at a lodging, camping or short-term rental property in Vermont, you must sign a Certificate of Compliance certifying that you have met the quarantine requirement or have traveled from an approved county with a low rate of active cases.
In general, we rely on every visitorâs and every Vermonterâs voluntary compliance of the Governorâs orders to protect the health and safety of all. Vermonters and visitors are encouraged to take responsible common-sense measures in our daily lives to make sure we all are following CDC and Vermont Department of Health guidelines to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Find more travel and quarantine information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.

question: How can I be safe from COVID-19 infection and prevent an overdose?
answer:
Substance use may increase the risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from COVID-19, but more evidence is needed. At the same time, an opioid overdose is an immediate risk to your life. Know that stimulants may also have fentanyl in them, an opioid. Below are some tips to help avoid an overdose or be better prepared if one happens and to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19.
If you are alone:

Call, text or send a Facebook or other type of message to someone you trust. Tell them youâre going to use and make a safety plan. For example, ask them to call you in a certain number of minutes. If they donât hear from you, they should follow your plan. This could include coming over to check on you, calling a family member to check on you, or calling 911.
Call Never Use Alone at 800-484-3731 or message them on Facebook. Theyâll wait while you use and call for emergency services if you donât respond after a certain period of time.
Have Naloxone with you. Put it where someone checking on you will easily see it.
Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

If youâre not alone:

Try to keep a 6-foot distance from the other people youâre with, unless you live with them. People who live in the same household donât need to stay 6 feet apart.
Anyone in the room should wear a face mask or covering if they are not using and not part of your household.
Make sure someone you trust has naloxone on hand, and they arenât using at the moment.
Let them know when you are using so they can check in and give naloxone if needed.
Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

Whenever and wherever you use, these tips can help prevent an overdose:

Use one drug at a time (donât mix).
Know your tolerance. Use less if you havenât used in a while, or if youâve been sick, lost weight, or if something else has lowered your tolerance.
Test for fentanyl or assume there is fentanyl in your supply.
Start low and go slow. You can use more later.
Use in a lower risk way, like snorting instead of injecting or smoking.
Consider getting on medication assisted treatment (methadone, bupe, suboxone, etc.).
Call 802-565-LINK or go to VTHelplink to find a treatment center.

About wearing face masks or coverings:
Wearing a mask reduces the risk of transmission of COVID-19. However, substance use can impact your breathing and wearing a mask can make it worse. Plus, if you canât take your own mask off (like if youâre nodding out), you shouldnât wear one. When using substances with other people, particularly opioids, you may choose to stay 6 feet apart and not wear masks.
More information:

Tips to prevent an opioid overdose (Harm Reduction Coalition)
Helping during an overdose and finding Naloxone (Health Department)
Guidance for People Who Use Substances on COVID-19 (Yale)
Safer Drug Use During the COVID-19 Outbreak (Harm Reduction Coalition)

question: Can I travel to or from Canada?
answer: Check the U.S. Customs Border Protection website and the Canadian Border Services Agency for current information about travel to Canada.

question: What details can you share about people who have died from COVID-19?
answer:
The total number of deaths across the state and for each county are updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. Below the map, you can find information on how the data for deaths are reported.
Information on the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the U.S. is available from the CDC.

question: How many people who have tested positive for or have symptoms of COVID-19 are in the hospitals?
answer: The number of people who are currently hospitalized with COVID-19 and the number of people who are suspected to have COVID-19 but have not yet been confirmed (reported as hospitalized under investigation) are updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. Below the map, you can find information on how the hospitalization data and data for people currently hospitalized are reported.

question: Why is Vermont reporting people who have tested for COVID-19 in the way that it is?
answer:
With the quickly changing situation, we continue to adjust reporting, looking for the best ways to communicate with the public. Information is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.
Weekly summaries of Vermont COVID-19 data include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.
We need to assume that we are all at risk of infection and follow these general precautions: keep a 6-foot distance from people you don't live with, wear a cloth face mask or covering when you can't keep 6 feet apart, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

question: What is the percent of people who tested positive for COVID-19 in Vermont?
answer: You can find the percent of people who tested positive in Vermont each week in the weekly data summary (page 7).

question: Can I donate unused personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answer:
Yes, the State of Vermont is accepting donations of specific medical-related supplies, including:

N95 masks
Surgical masks
Face shields
Surgical gowns
Thermometers
Thermometer covers
Gloves (nitrile or non-latex)
Hand sanitizer

Fill out the online COVID-19 Donation Form to donate.

question: Can you tell me more information about a person diagnosed with COVID-19?
answer:
In order to protect a personâs personal health information and privacy, we canât provide details about specific cases. We are focusing our efforts on contact tracing to help identify people who have been in close contact with a person who has tested positive for COVID-19. We will keep the public informed as we are able, including any known risk to the public.
Find up-to-date COVID-19 information on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
answer:
If you are a health care professional, you can quickly become temporarily licensed to provide care during the COVID-19 pandemic. You can be granted a temporary license if you:

Are licensed and in good standing in other states
Were licensed in Vermont, but your license lapsed in recent years

There are no fees of any kind to obtain a temporary emergency license.
To apply for a license or get more information about the process, contact the licensing authority for your profession:

Board of Medical Practice (medical doctors, physician assistants, and podiatrists) or 802-657-4223.
Office of Professional Regulation (other health care professions â including nurses and osteopathic physicians) or 802-828-1505.

question: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
answer:
Find tips from the CDC on how toÂ clean and disinfect your home routinely and when someone is sick.
Make sure you are using cleaning products and disinfectants safely. Follow these guidelines:

Wear protective gear (such as gloves and eye protection)
Use them in a well-ventilated area
Follow the directions on the label
Use no more than the amount recommended on the label
Use water at room temperature for dilution (unless the label says a different temperature)
Donât mix chemicals
Label diluted cleaning products
Store them out of reach of children and pets

You should never eat, drink, breathe or inject these products into your body or apply directly to your skin as they can cause serious harm. Do not wipe or bathe pets with these products or any other products that are not approved for animal use.
If you feel sick after using disinfectants, you can chat with the New England Poison Control Center on their website, call 1-800-222-1222 or text POISON to 85511.

question: When will I receive my test results?
answer:
Test results will be available typically within 1 to 3 days.
How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.
If you were tested at a Health Department popup testing site (for people without symptoms) andÂ you asked to receive your results by email, you will receive an email when your test results are ready, which is usually within 2 to 3 days. The email will prompt you to log in and get your results online where you may also print your results letter. If you asked to receive your results by mail, you will get a letter within 7 days of being tested.Â Find the list of Health Department tests sites.
If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.
If you were tested before an inpatient or outpatient procedure, you will receive your test results before your procedure from the health care provider who is doing the procedure.
If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.

question: Can I be tested for COVID-19?
answer:
While anyone can get tested, not everyone needs to get tested. The best way to protect yourself from COVID-19 is to follow a few key prevention tips. If you think you should be tested for COVID-19, talk with your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
The Health DepartmentÂ recommends testingÂ for:

People withÂ COVID-19 symptoms.
People who have hadÂ close contact (within 6 feet for about 15 minutes) with someone who tested positive for COVID-19.
People who are referred by their health care provider for testing for another reason.

We do not recommend people get tested before visiting another household or attending a gathering just to make sure they're okay.Â Testing only tells you if you had COVID-19 on the day you were tested. You could have already been exposed but may have been tested too early for it to show up on the test, or you could be exposed to COVID-19 after you are tested. Testing is notÂ prevention, and a negative test does not necessarily mean it is safe to gather with others.
We do not recommend people get tested frequently.Â We do not recommend routine, repeated testing just for peace of mind. While testing supplies are currently in adequate supply, we need to use what we have wisely.
There is no cost to individuals for the COVID-19 test.
The number of Vermonters who were tested for COVID-19 is updated daily on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.

question: Where can I get tested for COVID-19?
answer:
While anyone can get tested, not everyone needs to get tested. The best way to protect yourself from COVID-19 is to follow a few key prevention tips. If you think you should be tested for COVID-19, talk with your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
The Health DepartmentÂ recommends testingÂ for:

People withÂ COVID-19 symptoms.
People who have hadÂ close contact (within 6 feet for about 15 minutes) with someone who tested positive for COVID-19.
People who are referred by their health care provider for testing for another reason.

We do not recommend people get tested before visiting another household or attending a gathering just to make sure they're okay.Â Testing only tells you if you had COVID-19 on the day you were tested. You could have already been exposed but may have been tested too early for it to show up on the test, or you could be exposed to COVID-19 after you are tested. Testing is notÂ prevention, and a negative test does not necessarily mean it is safe to gather with others.
We do not recommend people get tested frequently.
We do not recommend routine, repeated testing just for peace of mind. While testing supplies are currently in adequate supply, we need to use what we have wisely.
Find more information about testing and testing locations including frequently asked questions about pop-up testing.
Find out what to do if you are sick from the CDC and what to do while youâre waiting for test results.

question: What does âinfectious periodâ mean?
answer:
The infectious period is the period of time where someone with COVID-19 has a high chance of spreading the virus to others. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested âÂ and continues until they have recovered.
People who had close interactions with the person with COVID-19 during this time are at risk and may be considered close contacts.

question: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answer:
It is not yet known if people whoÂ recoverÂ from COVID-19 can get infected again. Data to date show that a person who has had and recovered from COVID-19 may have low levels of virus in their bodies for up to 3 months after diagnosis. This means that if the person who has recovered from COVID-19 is retested within 3 months of initial infection, they may continue to have a positive test result, even though they are not spreading COVID-19.
There are no confirmed reports to date of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within 3 months of initial infection. However, additional research is ongoing. Therefore, if a person who has recovered from COVID-19 has new symptoms of COVID-19, the person may need an evaluation for reinfection, especially if the person has had close contact with someone infected with COVID-19. The person should isolate and contact a health care provider to be evaluated for other causes of their symptoms, and possibly retested.

question: What is monitoring?
answer: Monitoring means travelers or close contacts who are enrolled in Sara Alert for daily symptom check reminders. The Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard includes the number of people being monitored and the number of people who have completed monitoring and is updated every day.

question: Can I get the virus from food?
answer:
According to CDC, although the virus can survive for a short period on some surfaces, it is unlikely to be spread from domestic or international mail, products or packaging.
The COVID-19 virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
Learn from the CDC about safe handling of deliveries and mail and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

question: What is the Health Department doing?
answer:
The Health Department has put into place appropriate measures to protect businesses and Health Department staff. Emergencies and foodborne outbreak investigations are still being responded to during the COVID-19 pandemic.
If you have a complaint about a restaurant, you can submit an illness or sanitation complaint online, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221. Any complaint received about a food establishment not complying with the Governorâs orders is forwarded to the Office of the Attorney General for enforcement.

question: I’ve heard that home remedies can cure or prevent the virus.
answer:
There’s no evidence from the outbreak that eating garlic, sipping water every 15 minutes or taking vitamin C will protect people from the new coronavirus. Same goes for using essential oils, colloidal silver and steroids.
Some posts have suggested that putting sesame oil on your body or spraying yourself with alcohol or chlorine will kill the virus. That’s also false.

question: Can coronavirus travel by wind? Is it safe to go for a walk or exercise outside if someone jogs or bikes past me?
answer:
Coronavirus cannot travel very far in the air, the World Health Organization says.
The virus is mainly spread through small droplets from an infected person’s nose or mouth, which get released when a person coughs, sneezes or speaks. 
These droplets “are relatively heavy, do not travel far and quickly sink to the ground,” the WHO said. 
While the wind isn’t a big risk factor, contaminated surfaces are. Those respiratory droplets can land on surfaces such as tables, doorknobs and handrails — and subsequently infect others who touch those surfaces and later touch their eyes, nose or mouth. 
That’s why wearing a face mask won’t necessarily protect you from coronavirus. The primary benefit of wearing a mask is to protect others if you’re sick or an asymptomatic carrier of the virus.

question: Can you safely reuse a non-cloth mask that you can’t wash, like a disposable mask?
answer:
Yes you can, said Dr. Joseph Vinetz, an infectious diseases professor at Yale School of Medicine. 
To disinfect masks that you can’t wash, Vinetz recommends leaving them in a clean, safe place in your home for a few days. After that, it should no longer be infectious, as this coronavirus is known to survive on hard surfaces for only up to three days. 
You can reuse cloth masks, too. Just launder them between each use on a high-heat setting. 
Learn more about which masks you shouldn’t buy and how you can make your own (without having to sew) here.

question: What’s so different about coronavirus that we have to shut down businesses? Why practice social distancing now, when we didn’t during the SARS and swine flu epidemics?
answer:
Unlike SARS and swine flu, the novel coronavirus is both highly contagious and especially deadly, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. 
“SARS was also a coronavirus, and it was a new virus at the time,” Gupta said. “In the end, we know that SARS ended up infecting 8,000 people around the world and causing around 800 deaths. So very high fatality rate, but it didn’t turn out to be very contagious.”
The swine flu, or H1N1, “was very contagious and infected some 60 million people in the United States alone within a year,” Gupta said. “But it was far less lethal than the flu even — like 1/3 as lethal as the flu.” 
What makes the novel coronavirus different is that “this is both very contagious … and it appears to be far more lethal than the flu as well,” Gupta said. “So both those things, in combination I think, are why we’re taking this so seriously.”

question: This isolation is taking a toll on my mental health. And I’m starting to feel depressed and anxious about the pandemic. How can I get help?
answer:
The Crisis Text Line is available texting to 741741. Trained volunteers and crisis counselors are staffed 24/7, and the service is free. 
The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration Disaster Distress Helpline provides 24/7, 365-day-a-year crisis counseling and support to people experiencing emotional distress related to disasters. Call 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746 to connect with a trained crisis counselor.
For health care professionals and essential workers, For the Frontlines offers free 24/7 crisis counseling and support for workers dealing with stress, anxiety, fear or isolation related to coronavirus. 
For more resources, check out CNN’s guide to giving and getting help during the pandemic.

question: Will ingesting or injecting disinfectants, like the ones that kill viruses on surfaces, protect me against coronavirus or kill coronavirus if I already have it?
answer:
“That’s a bad idea,” said Dr. Colleen Kraft, an infectious diseases professor at Emory University School of Medicine. “It could definitely kill you.” 
President Donald Trump wondered aloud during a press conference whether there’s “a way we can do something like that, by injection inside or almost a cleaning.”
But the Reckitt Benckiser Group, which produces Lysol cleaning products, said “under no circumstance” should disinfectants be put into the human body.

question: Is it true young people with coronavirus are also having blood clots and strokes?
answer:
Yes, some young adults have suffered strokes after getting coronavirus. 
“The virus seems to be causing increased clotting in the large arteries, leading to severe stroke,” said Dr. Thomas Oxley, a neurosurgeon at Mount Sinai Health System in New York.
“Our report shows a seven-fold increase in incidence of sudden stroke in young patients during the past two weeks,” he said. “Most of these patients have no past medical history and were at home with either mild symptoms (or in two cases, no symptoms) of Covid.”
At least one patient has died, and others are in rehabilitation facilities, intensive care or in the stroke unit, Oxley said. Only one patient went home, but will require intense care.

question: What can we learn from how other countries handled coronavirus?
answer:
Singapore was initially praised for its clampdown on the virus. Even people who had no symptoms but tested positive had to be hospitalized until they tested negative. 
But Singapore was also relaxed, allowing businesses, churches, restaurants and schools to stay open during its first wave of the virus. And some communities were overlooked by government testing.
The number of cases in Singapore shot up, and the country suffered a strong second wave of coronavirus. 
By contrast, Germany, South Korea, Iceland and Taiwan have been able to suppress the virus. They also have among the lowest death rates from Covid-19 in the world. 
Taiwan was proactive, launching its Central Epidemic Command Center before the island even confirmed its first infection. 
Iceland required all its citizens returning to the country to undergo 14 days of quarantine – regardless of which country they traveled from.
Germany and South Korea quickly launched widespread testing and have some of the highest per-capita testing rates in the world. Their ability to identify and isolate those infected has helped prevent deadlier outcomes.

question: Can coronavirus stick to clothes? Do I need to wash my clothes right after encountering other people, like at the grocery store or while jogging?
answer:
“I don’t think you need to,” CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. 
Coronavirus can stay alive for up to three days on stainless steel and plastic. But clothing “is probably more like cardboard — it’s more absorbent, so the virus is unlikely to stay and last that long,” Gupta said. 
While covonravirus can stay alive on cardboard for up to 24 hours, viruses generally don’t stick well on surfaces that are in motion. 
“If you look at how viruses move through air, they kind of want to move around objects,” Gupta said. “They don’t want to necessarily land on objects. So if you’re moving as human body through the air … (it’s) unlikely to stick to your clothes.”

question: Can coronavirus spread through water, like in a swimming pool or hot tub?
answer:
“There is no evidence that COVID-19 can be spread to humans through the use of pools and hot tubs,” the CDC says. 
“Proper operation, maintenance, and disinfection (e.g., with chlorine and bromine) of pools and hot tubs should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.”
But health officials still advise staying at least 6 feet away from others because COVID-19 is a respiratory disease. In other words, you probably won’t get coronavirus from the water, but you could get coronavirus from someone close to you in the water. 
As for drinking water, doctors say you don’t need to worry about coronavirus in the tap water because most municipal drinking water systems should remove or inactivate the virus.

question: How can someone spread coronavirus when asymptomatic? If they’re not sneezing or coughing, how can they infect others?
answer:
It’s easy for asymptomatic people to spread coronavirus, said Dr. Anne Rimoin, an epidemiology professor at UCLA’s School of Public Health.
“When you speak, sometimes you’ll spit a little bit,” she said. “You’ll rub your nose. You’ll touch your mouth. You’ll rub your eyes. And then you’ll touch other surfaces, and then you will be spreading virus if you are infected and shedding asymptomatically.”

question: Will an antibody test show whether I’m immune and can go back to work?
answer:
Not necessarily. Antibodies are a body’s response to bacteria or viruses. But this novel coronavirus is so new, it’s still not clear whether having antibodies to it means you have long-term protection from getting reinfected. 
“The thing we don’t know yet is what is the relationship between the level of antibody and the degree of your protection,” Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told Snapchat’s “Good Luck America” show. 
“So you may be positive for an antibody, but not enough to protect you.” 
There’s also a risk that some antibody tests might confuse the novel coronavirus with other coronaviruses, like the ones that cause the common cold.

question: If novel coronavirus antibodies may or may not offer long-term immunity, how would a vaccine help?
answer:
In some cases, a vaccine might give stronger protection than antibodies produced after being infected, epidemiologist Dr. Larry Brilliant said. 
“There are actually six other coronavirus – MERS and SARS and four other viruses that create the common cold. They don’t seem to do very well at creating long-term immunity,” Brilliant said. 
“But we need to find out whether we can create a vaccine that creates more immunity [to the novel coronavirus] than the disease does. And that’s not so wild. Many of the vaccines that we’ve made in history are actually stronger than the virus is itself at creating immunity.”

question: Can I use vodka as hand sanitizer?
answer:
Please don’t. The CDC advises using hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
Vodka typically contains between 35% and 46% percent alcohol.
If the stores are out of hand sanitizer and you want to make your own, the Nebraska Medical Center offers this recipe:
What you’ll need:

2/3 cup 91% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol)
1/3 cup aloe vera gel
Mixing bowl
Spoon or something for whisking
Small container, such as a 3-oz. travel bottle
Optional: essential oil to give your hand sanitizer a fragrance

Directions:In a mixing bowl, stir isopropyl alcohol and aloe vera gel together until well blended.Add 8-10 drops of scented essential oil (optional, but nice). Stir.Pour the homemade hand sanitizer into an empty container and seal. Write “hand sanitizer” on a piece of masking tape and attach to the bottle.

question: Are smokers or vapers at higher risk? What if I only smoke weed?
answer:
This is not a good time to be vaping or smoking anything, including weed. 
“Vaping affects your lungs at every level. It affects the immune function in your nasal cavity by affecting cilia, which push foreign things out,” said Prof. Stanton Glantz, director of the Center for Tobacco Research Control and Education at University of California San Francisco.
When you vape, “the ability of your upper airways to clear viruses is compromised,” Glantz said.
Tobacco smokers are at especially high risk. In a study from China, where the first Covid-19 outbreak occurred, smokers were 14 times more likely to develop severe complications than non-smokers.
Even occasionally smoking marijuana can put you at greater risk.
“What happens to your airways when you smoke cannabis is that it causes some degree of inflammation, very similar to bronchitis, very similar to the type of inflammation that cigarette smoking can cause,” said pulmonologist Dr. Albert Rizzo, chief medical officer for the American Lung Association.
“Now you have some airway inflammation, and you get an infection on top of it. So yes, your chance of getting more complications is there.”

question: Can I get coronavirus through food? Is it safe to eat takeout from restaurants?
answer:
There’s no evidence that coronavirus can be transmitted through food, the CDC says. 
Even if coronavirus does get into your food, your stomach acid would kill it, said Dr. Angela Rasmussen, a virologist at Columbia University.
“When you eat any kind of food, whether it be hot or cold, that food is going to go straight down into your stomach, where there’s a high acidity, low-pH environment that will inactivate the virus,” she said.
But it’s a good idea to disinfect the takeout containers, CNN Chief Medical Correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta said. Coronavirus is a respiratory virus, and it’s easy to touch your face without realizing it.
If you don’t have disinfecting wipes, use your own plates or bowls to serve the food. Just make sure to wash your hands after transferring food from the containers.

question: My teenagers aren’t taking this seriously. Any advice?
answer:
Coronavirus isn’t just infecting young people. It’s killing young, healthy people as well. 
We’ve reported many stories about young people getting severely sick with or dying from coronavirus.
Dimitri Mitchell, 18, admits he had a “false sense of security.” But he was later hospitalized with coronavirus and now wants everyone to take it seriously. 
“I just want to make sure everybody knows that no matter what their age is, it can seriously affect them. And it can seriously mess them up, like it messed me up,” the Iowa teen said. 
He started feeling sick on St. Patrick’s Day, with just a small cough. “I thought at first it was just a normal cold. And then it started progressively getting worse,” he said. 
“Four days in, the really bad symptoms started coming along. I started having really bad outbreaks, like sweating, and my eyes were really watery. I was getting warmer and warmer, and I was super fatigued. … I would start experiencing the worst headaches I’ve ever felt in my life. They were absolutely horrible.”
Eventually, the teen had to be hospitalized. His mother said she worried he might “fall asleep and never wake up.” 
Mitchell is now recovering, but still has a cough almost a month later. 
“I just hope everybody’s responsible, because it’s nothing to joke about,” he said. “It’s a real problem, and I want everybody to make sure they’re following social distancing guidelines and the group limits. And just listen to all the rules and precautions and stay up to date with the news and make sure they’re informed.”

question: Does this pandemic have anything to do with the 5G network?
answer:
No. That’s just a hoax going around the internet.
“The theory that 5G might compromise the immune system and thus enable people to get sick from corona is based on nothing,” said Eric van Rongen, chairman of the International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection (ICNIRP). 
Learn more about how 5G really works and why this hoax makes no sense.

question: My ex and I have joint custody of our kids. Is it safe for them to go between two homes?
answer:
Ideally, you should limit your children’s potential exposures to coronavirus and work out the safest plan possible with your ex. 
The problem: Most state and county family courts are closed, or open only for emergencies involving abuse or endangerment. So if parents wanted to formally modify pre-existing custody agreements, they can’t.
But some states may be offering some flexibility during the pandemic. And there may be creative solutions, such as spending more time with one parent now in exchange for extra time with the other parent after the pandemic ends.

question: How long does coronavirus stay “alive” on surfaces?
answer:
Up to three days, depending on the surface. According to a study funded by the US National Institutes of Health:

The novel coronavirus is viable up to 72 hours after being placed on stainless steel and plastic.
It was viable up to four hours after being placed on copper, and up to 24 hours after being put on cardboard.
In aerosols, it was viable for three hours.

question: Will a pneumonia or flu vaccine help protect against coronavirus?
answer:
Some cases of coronavirus do lead to pneumonia. But the pneumonia vaccine won’t help.
“Vaccines against pneumonia, such as pneumococcal vaccine and Haemophilus influenza type B (Hib) vaccine, only help protect people from these specific bacterial infections,” according to Harvard Medical School.
“They do not protect against any coronavirus pneumonia.”
The flu shot does not protect against coronavirus. But it does help protect against a massive, unnecessary burden on hospitals already overwhelmed with coronavirus.
The CDC estimates about 140,000 to 810,000 people are hospitalized with the flu every year in the US. And about half of Americans don’t get vaccinated – including most children who die from the flu.

question: How long will we have to keep social distancing?
answer:
Probably for several months. But you might have to do it “over and over again,” since the outbreak could come in waves.
Research by the Imperial College in Great Britain “would suggest you have to institute these kinds of measures for five months, very vigorously,” said Dr. Celine Gounder, an infectious disease specialist at Bellevue Hospital Center. 
“And then you may be able to relax for a period. And then you would re-institute as the cases go up again. But we’re basically looking at doing this over and over and over again, even after a five-month period of strict social distancing, in order to curb cases until we have a vaccine.”
Health officials say we’re at least a year away from the first publicly available coronavirus vaccine.

question: Why is a cure taking so long?
answer:
An antiviral drug must be able to target the specific part of a virus’s life cycle that is necessary for it to reproduce, according to Harvard Medical School.
“In addition, an antiviral drug must be able to kill a virus without killing the human cell it occupies. And viruses are highly adaptive.”

question: Why are medical workers getting sick with or dying from coronavirus if they’re wearing protective gear? Does the viral load matter?
answer:
Many health care workers don’t actually have enough protective gear to handle the growing influx of coronavirus patients. 
Some have resorted to using plastic report covers as masks. The CDC said medical providers might have to use expired masks or reuse them between multiple patients. (This shortage is why the general public should not buy medical masks and instead make cloth masks at home.)
But it’s not just subpar protective gear that puts medical workers at risk. It’s also the amount of virus they’re exposed to. 
“The viral load — the amount of virus – does determine the severity of your illness,” emergency room physician Dr. Leana Wen said. “So that could happen in the case of health care workers who are exposed to a lot more Covid-19 as a result of their work — that they get more severely ill.”

question: Can I have the flu and coronavirus at the same time?
answer:
Yes. Testing positive for either the flu or coronavirus doesn’t exempt you from having the other at the same time. 
The flu and coronavirus share some common symptoms, such as fever and cough.
But many coronavirus patients suffer from shortness of breath, and some people with coronavirus lose their senses of taste or smell. But it’s important to note many people with coronavirus — possibly up to 50% — have no symptoms at all.
Learn more about the differences between flu, coronavirus and allergy symptoms here.

question: How many people with coronavirus don't have symptoms? Are they still contagious?
answer:
In one study, about 4 in 5 people with confirmed coronavirus in China were likely infected by people who didn’t know they had it, according to research published in the journal “Science.”
“These findings explain the rapid geographic spread of (coronavirus) and indicate containment of this virus will be particularly challenging,” researchers wrote.
In mid-March, the CDC said almost half of the 712 people with coronavirus who were on the Diamond Princess cruise ship didn’t have any symptoms when they tested positive.
And recent studies suggest 25% to 50% of coronavirus carriers don’t have symptoms.
In the US, “I think it could be as many as 1 in 3 walking around asymptomatic,” said New Jersey primary care physician Dr. Alex Salerno.
“We have tested some patients that have known exposure to COVID (coronavirus disease). They did not have temperature. Their pulse/(oxygen) was OK.”
Aside from social distancing and frequent hand washing, Salerno said more testing of people without symptoms is essential.
When asymptomatic carriers test positive, “we isolate them, and we separate them from the people who are not positive,” Salerno said. If more asymptomatic people got tested, “we could get people back to work safely.”
But there haven’t been nearly enough tests in the US for everyone who wants one, due to shortages, delays and faulty test kits.

question: If there’s no cure, why go to the hospital unless you have a breathing problem?
answer:
Most coronavirus patients don’t need to be hospitalized. “The vast majority of people – about 80% – will do well without any specific intervention,” said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
Those patients should get plenty of rest, hydrate frequently and take fever-reducing medication.
“The current guidance – and this may change – is that if you have symptoms that are similar to the cold and the flu and these are mild symptoms to moderate symptoms, stay at home and try to manage them,” said Dr. Patrice Harris, president of the American Medical Association. 
But about 20% of coronavirus patients get advanced disease. “Older patients and individuals who have underlying medical conditions or are immunocompromised should contact their physician early in the course of even mild illness,” the CDC says.
The CDC also says you should get immediate help if you have: 

Trouble breathing
Persistent pain or pressure in the chest
Sudden confusion 
Bluish lips or face

“This list is not all inclusive,” the CDC says. “Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.”

question: Why is everyone stocking up on bottled water? Is the water supply at risk?
answer:
No, the water supply is not at risk.
“The COVID-19 virus has not been detected in drinking water,” the CDC says. “Conventional water treatment methods that use filtration and disinfection, such as those in most municipal drinking water systems, should remove or inactivate the virus that causes COVID-19.”
So there’s no need to hoard drinking water, said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Fauci said he and his wife are still drinking tap water.

question: My child’s school is closed, and we need a babysitter. How do I keep my family safe with someone new in the house?
answer:
The Harvard Medical School offers several tips, including: 

choosing a babysitter who has minimal exposures to other people besides your family
limiting the number of babysitters. If you can keep it to one, that’s ideal. But if you need multple babysitters, keep the number as low as possible
making sure the babysitter understands he or she needs to practice social distancing and limits physical interaction with your children as much as possible
telling the babysitter that he or she must not come to your house if feeling even the slightest bit sick, or has had known exposure to coronavirus
making sure everyone washes their hands frequently throughout the day, especially before eating.

question: If people can spread the virus without showing any symptoms, how can I tell who’s infected and who’s not?
answer:
You can’t, said Dr. James Phillips, chief of disaster and operational medicine at George Washington University Hospital.
“We’re so far behind on testing, there’s only one way we can be certain not to transmit the virus and be certain not to get it ourselves: We need to start treating every person as though they have this, ” Phillips said. 
“And everyone needs to treat us like we have it, and socially distance ourselves in that manner. Because until we have (enough) testing, we don’t know who has this. And we’re not sure when they start spreading it.” 
That’s why it’s so critical to avoid crowds, stay at least 6 feet away from others, wash or disinfect your hands, and stop touching your face.

question: How do I safely take care of someone who’s sick?
answer:
With the shortage of coronavirus testing nationwide, it may be difficult to know whether your loved one has coronavirus or another illness.
                So it’s critical to play it safe and not infect yourself and, in turn, others. The CDC suggests: 

Giving the sick person their own room to stay in, if possible. Keep the door closed.
Having only one person serve as the caretaker.
Asking the sick person to wear a face mask, if they are able to. If the mask causes breathing difficulties, then the caretaker should wear a mask instead.

question: What are the symptoms?
answer:
Fever, dry cough and difficulty breathing are hallmarks of coronavirus. 
Symptoms may appear anywhere from 2 days to 2 weeks after exposure, the CDC says. But some people get no symptoms at all and can infect others without knowing it.
The illness varies in its severity, and many patients can recover at home in isolation.

question: Can coronavirus go through skin and into the body?
answer:
“It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads,” the CDC says. 
More often than not, people get coronavirus through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
“These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs,” the CDC says.

question: What exactly does 'older' adults mean? What is the age threshold?
answer:
The CDC says “older adults“ and people with serious chronic medical conditions “are at higher risk of getting very sick from this illness.” 
Anyone over 60 and those with underlying health problems should try to avoid places with large crowds – such as movie theaters, busy malls and even religious services, infectious disease experts say.
“This ought to be top of mind for people over 60, and those with underlying health problems,” said Dr. William Schaffner, a Vanderbilt University professor and longtime CDC adviser.
But why is age 60 often used as a threshold for those who need to be extra cautious?
“(The) average age of death for people from coronavirus is 80. Average age of people who need medical attention is age 60,” US Surgeon General Jerome Adams said. 
Read more about what adults 60 and older should do to prevent coronavirus.

question: What can I do if my loved one suspects they have coronavirus?
answer:
Don’t visit family members with suspected illness – keep up with them virtually.
                If that loved one lives with you, limit contact with them and avoid using the same bathroom or bedroom, the CDC advises.
If they’ve been diagnosed, they may be able to recover at home in isolation. Separate yourself as much as possible from your infected family member and keep animals away, too. Continue to use separate restrooms and regularly disinfect them with EPA-approved products.
Stock up on groceries and household supplies for them while they can’t travel outside and minimize trips to stores. Wash your hands frequently and avoid sharing personal items with the infected person.
If you suspect you’re developing symptoms, stay home and call your physician.

question: Should I disinfect my groceries? If so, how?
answer:
“I would suggest wiping down external surfaces of canned or wrapped foods,” said Dr. Celine Gounder, an infectious disease specialist at Bellevue Hospital Center. 
“You should be washing your vegetables (and) produce anyway,” she said. “But I think making sure you sanitize your hands, wash your hands after you do all that – after you unpack all your groceries – is also a key step.”

question: The stores are all out of disinfectant sprays and hand sanitizer. Can I make my own?
answer:
Yes, you can make both at home.
“Unexpired household bleach will be effective against coronaviruses when properly diluted” if you’re trying to kill coronavirus on a non-porous surface, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. 
The CDC’s recipe calls for diluting 5 tablespoons (or ⅓ cup) of bleach per gallon of water, or 4 teaspoons of bleach per quart of water. 
You can also make your own hand sanitizer. The Nebraska Medical Center – famous for its biocontainment unit and treatment of Ebola patients – offers this recipe:
What you’ll need:
